definition: A finite set of symbols used to construct words in a language. For example, Σ = {0, 1} is a common binary alphabet.
A finite sequence of symbols from an alphabet. For example, 0010 is a word over the alphabet Σ = {0, 1}.
A set of words, often defined over a specific alphabet. For example, the set {0010, 00000000, ϵ} is a language over Σ = {0, 1}.
A word with no symbols, having a length of 0. It is distinct from the empty set (∅) and the set containing the empty word ({ϵ}).
A set containing no elements. It is distinct from the empty word (ϵ) and the set containing the empty word ({ϵ}).
The set of all possible words (including the empty word) that can be formed from an alphabet Σ. For example, if Σ = {0, 1}, then Σ* includes words like ϵ, 0, 1, 00, 01, etc.
An operation on words or languages where two words or sets of words are combined. For example, if M = {ϵ, a, aa} and N = {b, c}, then MN = {b, c, ab, ac, aab, aac}.
Used to denote iterated concatenation of a word or language. For example, u^2 = uu, and L^3 = LLL.
The set of all possible concatenations of 0 or more words from a language L. For example, if L = {a, ab}, then L* = {ϵ, a, ab, aa, aab, aba, ...}.
A finite automaton where each state has exactly one transition for each symbol in the alphabet.
A finite automaton where a state can have multiple transitions for the same symbol or transitions without consuming input (epsilon transitions).
A sequence of characters defining a search pattern, often used to describe regular languages.
A formal grammar that can generate all strings in a context-free language.
An abstract computational model that manipulates symbols on a tape according to a set of rules.
The property of a problem being solvable by an algorithm in a finite amount of time.
The problem of determining whether a given Turing machine will halt on a given input. It is undecidable.
The set of all possible subsets of a set A. For example, if A = {a, b}, then P(A) = {∅, {a}, {b}, {a, b}}.
A word that reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 'abba' is a palindrome over the English alphabet.
A language with a finite number of words. For example, {0010, 00000000, ϵ} is a finite language over Σ = {0, 1}.
A language with an infinite number of words. For example, Σ* for any non-empty alphabet Σ is an infinite language.
Concatenation of languages is associative: L(MN) = (LM)N.
The set {ϵ} is the unit of concatenation: L{ϵ} = L = {ϵ}L.
Concatenation distributes through set union: L(M ∪ N) = LM ∪ LN and (L ∪ M)N = LN ∪ MN.
